sumDiv0.text: That was after having spent about 20 years together with African institutions studying hunger in Africa, so I was sort of expected to know a little about the world.

sumDiv1.text: I won't put you at a test here, but it's Turkey, which is highest there, Poland, Russia, Pakistan and South Africa.

sumDiv2.text: Because the chimpanzee would score half right if I gave them two bananas with Sri Lanka and Turkey.

sumDiv3.text: I did also an unethical study of the professors of the Karolinska Institute -- that hands out the Nobel Prize in Medicine, and they are on par with the chimpanzee there.

sumDiv4.text: The size of the bubble is the population, and on this axis here I put fertility rate.

sumDiv5.text: Here I put life expectancy at birth, from 30 years in some countries up to about 70 years.And 1962, there was really a group of countries here that was industrialized countries, and they had small families and long lives.

sumDiv6.text: Your yellow ones here are the Arabic countries, and they get larger families, but they -- no, longer life, but not larger families.

sumDiv7.text: Let me make a comparison directly between the United States of America and Vietnam.1964: America had small families and long life; Vietnam had large families and short lives.

sumDiv8.text: And if we look where the income ends up -- the income -- this is 100 percent the world's annual income.

sumDiv9.text: And on top of that, we can put East Europe, we can put East Asia, and we put South Asia.
